IT/ Software Applications Manager Oceanside, CA (San Diego Metro) 135-160k+ DOE    About Us:   We are a growing leading manufacturer and supplier of premium consumer products for the automobile industry. We are seeking a dynamic IT Development Manager to lead our data, infrastructure, and software engineering team and drive the integration and optimization of our critical business systems.   Job Summary:   We are looking for an experienced IT Development Manager with exceptional communication and leadership skills to oversee the planning, execution, and success of our software development and integration projects. The ideal candidate will have a strong background in managing enterprise applications, particularly ERP, WMS, E-commerce, and EDI integrations. This role requires a hands-on manager who can lead a team of software engineers, foster their growth, and ensure alignment with business objectives. This role involves approximately 40% hands-on work.   Responsibilities: â€¢	Lead and manage a team of software engineers, providing mentorship. â€¢	Plan and implement enterprise applications and related integrations (ERP, WMS, E-commerce, EDI). â€¢	Design, develop, and architect solutions that deliver value to the organization. â€¢	Manage the lifecycle of enterprise applications. â€¢	Collaborate with stakeholders to define project scope and objectives. â€¢	Automate release pipelines and testing. â€¢	Actively manage project timelines and resources.  Required Skills and Experience:  â€¢	Excellent communication skills. â€¢	Proven leadership and team management skills. â€¢	10+ years of experience in IT and software engineering roles. â€¢	5+ years of experience in a leadership role. â€¢	Experience implementing and maintaining enterprise applications (ERP, WMS). â€¢	Experience with ERP integrations (EDI, E-commerce). â€¢	Experience with .Net C# and other object-oriented programming languages. â€¢	Proficiency in DevOps management tools and code repositories. â€¢	Experience with SQL and SQL server. â€¢	Experience with cloud platforms (Azure and/or AWS). â€¢	Manufacturing experience is a plus.  What We Offer:  â€¢	Competitive Salary â€¢	Comprehensive Benefits Package â€¢	Growing department and team  More information, or to apply: https://smpl.is/a61bj  hashtag#ITjobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#leadership hashtag#techjobs hashtag#opportunity

Why I Have Declined a Fully-Remote $7,150 Net/Month Offer.Recently, I was actively job hunting and got pretty far with a promising opportunity. I completed the technical task, passed the interviews, and received an offer from a well-known international company with a strong media presence and a quite ethical business model.The position was for a DevOps engineer. The terms were excellent: official B2B contract, fully remote work - I could work from anywhere, even a small village back home in Kazakhstan. They offered a three-week paid company bootcamp in Cyprus and a long-term collaboration. Some of their employees had been with the company for over 12 years - it sounded like a dream job.I had already arranged an early exit from my current work, started looking for tickets to Cyprus, and was mentally ready to sign the contract.But when the actual contract arrived, although it was generally fine, one detail immediately caught my attention: there was no liability limitation clause.For employees under standard labor law in almost any country, it is usually not an issue because labor laws protect employees against unlimited financial liability. But for B2B or contractor agreements, things are different - unless explicitly stated otherwise, the contractor can be held fully liable.As someone with significant DevOps experience, I know firsthand that mistakes can be costly. It might only take a few hours to accidentally cause damages worth several months of my salary. While Iâ€™ve never had a serious incident myself, I understand that no one is immune to risk - itâ€™s part of the job.So, I politely asked to add a simple clause: to cap the liability to a maximum of three months' salary.The HR representative immediately refused, saying, "This is our standard contract. Everyone signs it, and so should you." They told me theyâ€™ve never had any lawsuits and insisted there was no need to change anything. Moreover, I was repeatedly told that literally no one in the whole company, including legal, HR, and the hiring manager, understands my concern and I should just sign the contract as it is. The hiring manager allegedly is also under the same contract, has caused damages ranging into hundreds of thousands of USD before, and "everything was fine."I spent a lot of time carefully explaining my concern - that itâ€™s not about mistrust but about basic risk management - but they stuck to their position. Eventually, they gave me an ultimatum: sign it as-is, or walk away.I chose to walk away.I've been in this industry long enough to know: mistakes will happen eventually, and when they do, they can be very expensive. Signing a contract with unlimited personal liability would be like playing Russian roulette with my financial future. In my opinion it just wasn't worth it.

ğŸš§ How I Overcame a Major Project Failure ğŸ¤A few years ago, I was leading the deployment of a Node.js application to AWS Lightsail. Everything looked great on paper â€” the code was solid, the pipeline was configured, and the deadline was tight, but doable.Then came the failure.Right after deployment, the application didn't serve as expected. I could SSH into the server, the services were running, but users kept seeing a blank page. Logs showed no clear errors. We had to halt the rollout, and stakeholders were understandably frustrated.The problem? The app was starting from the wrong entry point â€” we had deployed index.ts, but our CI/CD pipeline defaulted to the wrong directory (/var/www/html). It was a classic case of â€œit worked on my machineâ€ â€” and it cost us valuable time.ğŸ’¡ What I Learned:Never assume environment consistency. Document and test deployment directories explicitly.Automate sanity checks post-deployment (even a simple curl to the home page couldâ€™ve flagged this earlier).Own the failure, but focus on the fix. I worked late into the night with my team, rewrote the pipeline, and redeployed from the correct entry point.Most importantly, I learned to communicate transparently with stakeholders during a crisis.Today, our deployments are smoother, and Iâ€™ve grown more confident handling surprises in production.ğŸ—£ï¸ Have you ever had a project crash and burn, only to bounce back stronger? Letâ€™s talk â€” your comeback story might inspire someone today.hashtag#TechLeadership hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CICD hashtag#FailureToSuccess hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#AWS hashtag#Lightsail hashtag#Nodejs hashtag#Reflection

Iâ€™m now firmly in my third month of un(der)employment. Itâ€™s been an interesting one.ğŸ‘¨ğŸ¼â€ğŸ’» Good News: I began working a FT job recently which is in a completely different world than where I came from, but in many ways not that different at all. Itâ€™s enough money to keep me off the stateâ€™s dime but just barely. Itâ€™s a shadow of my most recent salary and the first time Iâ€™ve had to actually punch a clock in (uuuugh) 30 years or more BUT itâ€™s a job and in lieu of a world that seems more likely to cut off its nose to spite its face than do anything that makes sense at all, Iâ€™ll take it. This is something I should have done the last time I was out of work. Idle hands, and all that.ğŸ‰ It shortens the resume gap, and if any of my potential future employers are reading this hopefully theyâ€™ll see that I am willing to do anything it takes to get the job done. Even if that job is just making the grocery budget manageable.â›”ï¸ DO NOT let your pride or ego get in your way. Take that random PT or FT gig while youâ€™re still seeking your next main gig. Get out of the house. Enjoy the process. You never know what might happen.â˜‘ï¸ Worst case - itâ€™s another hard reset and I make something cool out of this. Iâ€™ll add some new tools to my arsenal, meet some genuinely awesome people, and not be bored in the interim. Wouldnâ€™t be the first timeâ€¦ğŸ™ğŸ» Thatâ€™s how I got into live events, after all.ğŸš¨ This job is also being super considerate about letting me take short-term event contracts as they come along, too. Itâ€™s a win-win, really.ğŸ¥º A lot of people I know continue to get laid off/made redundant/get Trumped. I hate it. Good people. Smart people. I am pulling for you all to land as close to what you want or need as you can. I am trying to share as many of your hashtag#OpenToWork posts as possible to help. IT/ Software Applications Manager Oceanside, CA (San Diego Metro) 135-160k+ DOE    About Us:   We are a growing leading manufacturer and supplier of premium consumer products for the automobile industry. We are seeking a dynamic IT Development Manager to lead our data, infrastructure, and software engineering team and drive the integration and optimization of our critical business systems.   Job Summary:   We are looking for an experienced IT Development Manager with exceptional communication and leadership skills to oversee the planning, execution, and success of our software development and integration projects. The ideal candidate will have a strong background in managing enterprise applications, particularly ERP, WMS, E-commerce, and EDI integrations. This role requires a hands-on manager who can lead a team of software engineers, foster their growth, and ensure alignment with business objectives. This role involves approximately 40% hands-on work.   Responsibilities: â€¢	Lead and manage a team of software engineers, providing mentorship. â€¢	Plan and implement enterprise applications and related integrations (ERP, WMS, E-commerce, EDI). â€¢	Design, develop, and architect solutions that deliver value to the organization. â€¢	Manage the lifecycle of enterprise applications. â€¢	Collaborate with stakeholders to define project scope and objectives. â€¢	Automate release pipelines and testing. â€¢	Actively manage project timelines and resources.  Required Skills and Experience:  â€¢	Excellent communication skills. â€¢	Proven leadership and team management skills. â€¢	10+ years of experience in IT and software engineering roles. â€¢	5+ years of experience in a leadership role. â€¢	Experience implementing and maintaining enterprise applications (ERP, WMS). â€¢	Experience with ERP integrations (EDI, E-commerce). â€¢	Experience with .Net C# and other object-oriented programming languages. â€¢	Proficiency in DevOps management tools and code repositories. â€¢	Experience with SQL and SQL server. â€¢	Experience with cloud platforms (Azure and/or AWS). â€¢	Manufacturing experience is a plus.  What We Offer:  â€¢	Competitive Salary â€¢	Comprehensive Benefits Package â€¢	Growing department and team  More information, or to apply: https://smpl.is/a61bj  hashtag#ITjobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#leadership hashtag#techjobs hashtag#opportunity

Why I Have Declined a Fully-Remote $7,150 Net/Month Offer.Recently, I was actively job hunting and got pretty far with a promising opportunity. I completed the technical task, passed the interviews, and received an offer from a well-known international company with a strong media presence and a quite ethical business model.The position was for a DevOps engineer. The terms were excellent: official B2B contract, fully remote work - I could work from anywhere, even a small village back home in Kazakhstan. They offered a three-week paid company bootcamp in Cyprus and a long-term collaboration. Some of their employees had been with the company for over 12 years - it sounded like a dream job.I had already arranged an early exit from my current work, started looking for tickets to Cyprus, and was mentally ready to sign the contract.But when the actual contract arrived, although it was generally fine, one detail immediately caught my attention: there was no liability limitation clause.For employees under standard labor law in almost any country, it is usually not an issue because labor laws protect employees against unlimited financial liability. But for B2B or contractor agreements, things are different - unless explicitly stated otherwise, the contractor can be held fully liable.As someone with significant DevOps experience, I know firsthand that mistakes can be costly. It might only take a few hours to accidentally cause damages worth several months of my salary. While Iâ€™ve never had a serious incident myself, I understand that no one is immune to risk - itâ€™s part of the job.So, I politely asked to add a simple clause: to cap the liability to a maximum of three months' salary.The HR representative immediately refused, saying, "This is our standard contract. Everyone signs it, and so should you." They told me theyâ€™ve never had any lawsuits and insisted there was no need to change anything. Moreover, I was repeatedly told that literally no one in the whole company, including legal, HR, and the hiring manager, understands my concern and I should just sign the contract as it is. The hiring manager allegedly is also under the same contract, has caused damages ranging into hundreds of thousands of USD before, and "everything was fine."I spent a lot of time carefully explaining my concern - that itâ€™s not about mistrust but about basic risk management - but they stuck to their position. Eventually, they gave me an ultimatum: sign it as-is, or walk away.I chose to walk away.I've been in this industry long enough to know: mistakes will happen eventually, and when they do, they can be very expensive. Signing a contract with unlimited personal liability would be like playing Russian roulette with my financial future. In my opinion it just wasn't worth it.

ğŸš§ How I Overcame a Major Project Failure ğŸ¤A few years ago, I was leading the deployment of a Node.js application to AWS Lightsail. Everything looked great on paper â€” the code was solid, the pipeline was configured, and the deadline was tight, but doable.Then came the failure.Right after deployment, the application didn't serve as expected. I could SSH into the server, the services were running, but users kept seeing a blank page. Logs showed no clear errors. We had to halt the rollout, and stakeholders were understandably frustrated.The problem? The app was starting from the wrong entry point â€” we had deployed index.ts, but our CI/CD pipeline defaulted to the wrong directory (/var/www/html). It was a classic case of â€œit worked on my machineâ€ â€” and it cost us valuable time.ğŸ’¡ What I Learned:Never assume environment consistency. Document and test deployment directories explicitly.Automate sanity checks post-deployment (even a simple curl to the home page couldâ€™ve flagged this earlier).Own the failure, but focus on the fix. I worked late into the night with my team, rewrote the pipeline, and redeployed from the correct entry point.Most importantly, I learned to communicate transparently with stakeholders during a crisis.Today, our deployments are smoother, and Iâ€™ve grown more confident handling surprises in production.ğŸ—£ï¸ Have you ever had a project crash and burn, only to bounce back stronger? Letâ€™s talk â€” your comeback story might inspire someone today.hashtag#TechLeadership hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CICD hashtag#FailureToSuccess hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#AWS hashtag#Lightsail hashtag#Nodejs hashtag#Reflection

Iâ€™m now firmly in my third month of un(der)employment. Itâ€™s been an interesting one.ğŸ‘¨ğŸ¼â€ğŸ’» Good News: I began working a FT job recently which is in a completely different world than where I came from, but in many ways not that different at all. Itâ€™s enough money to keep me off the stateâ€™s dime but just barely. Itâ€™s a shadow of my most recent salary and the first time Iâ€™ve had to actually punch a clock in (uuuugh) 30 years or more BUT itâ€™s a job and in lieu of a world that seems more likely to cut off its nose to spite its face than do anything that makes sense at all, Iâ€™ll take it. This is something I should have done the last time I was out of work. Idle hands, and all that.ğŸ‰ It shortens the resume gap, and if any of my potential future employers are reading this hopefully theyâ€™ll see that I am willing to do anything it takes to get the job done. Even if that job is just making the grocery budget manageable.â›”ï¸ DO NOT let your pride or ego get in your way. Take that random PT or FT gig while youâ€™re still seeking your next main gig. Get out of the house. Enjoy the process. You never know what might happen.â˜‘ï¸ Worst case - itâ€™s another hard reset and I make something cool out of this. Iâ€™ll add some new tools to my arsenal, meet some genuinely awesome people, and not be bored in the interim. Wouldnâ€™t be the first timeâ€¦ğŸ™ğŸ» Thatâ€™s how I got into live events, after all.ğŸš¨ This job is also being super considerate about letting me take short-term event contracts as they come along, too. Itâ€™s a win-win, really.ğŸ¥º A lot of people I know continue to get laid off/made redundant/get Trumped. I hate it. Good people. Smart people. I am pulling for you all to land as close to what you want or need as you can. I am trying to share as many of your hashtag#OpenToWork posts as possible to help. IT/ Software Applications Manager Oceanside, CA (San Diego Metro) 135-160k+ DOE    About Us:   We are a growing leading manufacturer and supplier of premium consumer products for the automobile industry. We are seeking a dynamic IT Development Manager to lead our data, infrastructure, and software engineering team and drive the integration and optimization of our critical business systems.   Job Summary:   We are looking for an experienced IT Development Manager with exceptional communication and leadership skills to oversee the planning, execution, and success of our software development and integration projects. The ideal candidate will have a strong background in managing enterprise applications, particularly ERP, WMS, E-commerce, and EDI integrations. This role requires a hands-on manager who can lead a team of software engineers, foster their growth, and ensure alignment with business objectives. This role involves approximately 40% hands-on work.   Responsibilities: â€¢	Lead and manage a team of software engineers, providing mentorship. â€¢	Plan and implement enterprise applications and related integrations (ERP, WMS, E-commerce, EDI). â€¢	Design, develop, and architect solutions that deliver value to the organization. â€¢	Manage the lifecycle of enterprise applications. â€¢	Collaborate with stakeholders to define project scope and objectives. â€¢	Automate release pipelines and testing. â€¢	Actively manage project timelines and resources.  Required Skills and Experience:  â€¢	Excellent communication skills. â€¢	Proven leadership and team management skills. â€¢	10+ years of experience in IT and software engineering roles. â€¢	5+ years of experience in a leadership role. â€¢	Experience implementing and maintaining enterprise applications (ERP, WMS). â€¢	Experience with ERP integrations (EDI, E-commerce). â€¢	Experience with .Net C# and other object-oriented programming languages. â€¢	Proficiency in DevOps management tools and code repositories. â€¢	Experience with SQL and SQL server. â€¢	Experience with cloud platforms (Azure and/or AWS). â€¢	Manufacturing experience is a plus.  What We Offer:  â€¢	Competitive Salary â€¢	Comprehensive Benefits Package â€¢	Growing department and team  More information, or to apply: https://smpl.is/a61bj  hashtag#ITjobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#leadership hashtag#techjobs hashtag#opportunity

Why I Have Declined a Fully-Remote $7,150 Net/Month Offer.Recently, I was actively job hunting and got pretty far with a promising opportunity. I completed the technical task, passed the interviews, and received an offer from a well-known international company with a strong media presence and a quite ethical business model.The position was for a DevOps engineer. The terms were excellent: official B2B contract, fully remote work - I could work from anywhere, even a small village back home in Kazakhstan. They offered a three-week paid company bootcamp in Cyprus and a long-term collaboration. Some of their employees had been with the company for over 12 years - it sounded like a dream job.I had already arranged an early exit from my current work, started looking for tickets to Cyprus, and was mentally ready to sign the contract.But when the actual contract arrived, although it was generally fine, one detail immediately caught my attention: there was no liability limitation clause.For employees under standard labor law in almost any country, it is usually not an issue because labor laws protect employees against unlimited financial liability. But for B2B or contractor agreements, things are different - unless explicitly stated otherwise, the contractor can be held fully liable.As someone with significant DevOps experience, I know firsthand that mistakes can be costly. It might only take a few hours to accidentally cause damages worth several months of my salary. While Iâ€™ve never had a serious incident myself, I understand that no one is immune to risk - itâ€™s part of the job.So, I politely asked to add a simple clause: to cap the liability to a maximum of three months' salary.The HR representative immediately refused, saying, "This is our standard contract. Everyone signs it, and so should you." They told me theyâ€™ve never had any lawsuits and insisted there was no need to change anything. Moreover, I was repeatedly told that literally no one in the whole company, including legal, HR, and the hiring manager, understands my concern and I should just sign the contract as it is. The hiring manager allegedly is also under the same contract, has caused damages ranging into hundreds of thousands of USD before, and "everything was fine."I spent a lot of time carefully explaining my concern - that itâ€™s not about mistrust but about basic risk management - but they stuck to their position. Eventually, they gave me an ultimatum: sign it as-is, or walk away.I chose to walk away.I've been in this industry long enough to know: mistakes will happen eventually, and when they do, they can be very expensive. Signing a contract with unlimited personal liability would be like playing Russian roulette with my financial future. In my opinion it just wasn't worth it.

My Friday thought for today! â€œHiring Indigenous talent isnâ€™t just about being inclusiveâ€”itâ€™s about empowering the future of work."As an Indigenous woman, Iâ€™ve often felt the weight of walking into interviews wondering if Iâ€™d be seen, heard, or truly considered. When I applied to Clear Seas I was nervous. I didnâ€™t think Iâ€™d get the jobâ€”I didnâ€™t tick every single box on the job posting.  But here I am 5 years later, loving and always learning in my role as Director of Indigenous Programs. Too often, Indigenous professionals are overlooked. Told weâ€™re not â€œqualifiedâ€ enough. Told we donâ€™t quite â€œfit.â€ But hereâ€™s what I want to say to every employer out there: Indigenous people are more than survivors of colonization and residential schoolsâ€”we are leaders.We bring with us generations of knowledge, a spirit of adaptability, and an openness to learning and growth. We are connectors. Listeners. Innovators. And when we apply for roles in your organization, weâ€™re not just looking for a jobâ€”weâ€™re offering *you* a chance to work *with us.*So, yesâ€”hire Indigenous professionals. Not just because itâ€™s good for reconciliation, or because it checks a box. Do it because weâ€™re powerful. ğŸš§ How I Overcame a Major Project Failure ğŸ¤A few years ago, I was leading the deployment of a Node.js application to AWS Lightsail. Everything looked great on paper â€” the code was solid, the pipeline was configured, and the deadline was tight, but doable.Then came the failure.Right after deployment, the application didn't serve as expected. I could SSH into the server, the services were running, but users kept seeing a blank page. Logs showed no clear errors. We had to halt the rollout, and stakeholders were understandably frustrated.The problem? The app was starting from the wrong entry point â€” we had deployed index.ts, but our CI/CD pipeline defaulted to the wrong directory (/var/www/html). It was a classic case of â€œit worked on my machineâ€ â€” and it cost us valuable time.ğŸ’¡ What I Learned:Never assume environment consistency. Document and test deployment directories explicitly.Automate sanity checks post-deployment (even a simple curl to the home page couldâ€™ve flagged this earlier).Own the failure, but focus on the fix. I worked late into the night with my team, rewrote the pipeline, and redeployed from the correct entry point.Most importantly, I learned to communicate transparently with stakeholders during a crisis.Today, our deployments are smoother, and Iâ€™ve grown more confident handling surprises in production.ğŸ—£ï¸ Have you ever had a project crash and burn, only to bounce back stronger? Letâ€™s talk â€” your comeback story might inspire someone today.hashtag#TechLeadership hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CICD hashtag#FailureToSuccess hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#AWS hashtag#Lightsail hashtag#Nodejs hashtag#Reflection

IT/ Software Applications Manager Oceanside, CA (San Diego Metro) 135-160k+ DOE    About Us:   We are a growing leading manufacturer and supplier of premium consumer products for the automobile industry. We are seeking a dynamic IT Development Manager to lead our data, infrastructure, and software engineering team and drive the integration and optimization of our critical business systems.   Job Summary:   We are looking for an experienced IT Development Manager with exceptional communication and leadership skills to oversee the planning, execution, and success of our software development and integration projects. The ideal candidate will have a strong background in managing enterprise applications, particularly ERP, WMS, E-commerce, and EDI integrations. This role requires a hands-on manager who can lead a team of software engineers, foster their growth, and ensure alignment with business objectives. This role involves approximately 40% hands-on work.   Responsibilities: â€¢	Lead and manage a team of software engineers, providing mentorship. â€¢	Plan and implement enterprise applications and related integrations (ERP, WMS, E-commerce, EDI). â€¢	Design, develop, and architect solutions that deliver value to the organization. â€¢	Manage the lifecycle of enterprise applications. â€¢	Collaborate with stakeholders to define project scope and objectives. â€¢	Automate release pipelines and testing. â€¢	Actively manage project timelines and resources.  Required Skills and Experience:  â€¢	Excellent communication skills. â€¢	Proven leadership and team management skills. â€¢	10+ years of experience in IT and software engineering roles. â€¢	5+ years of experience in a leadership role. â€¢	Experience implementing and maintaining enterprise applications (ERP, WMS). â€¢	Experience with ERP integrations (EDI, E-commerce). â€¢	Experience with .Net C# and other object-oriented programming languages. â€¢	Proficiency in DevOps management tools and code repositories. â€¢	Experience with SQL and SQL server. â€¢	Experience with cloud platforms (Azure and/or AWS). â€¢	Manufacturing experience is a plus.  What We Offer:  â€¢	Competitive Salary â€¢	Comprehensive Benefits Package â€¢	Growing department and team  More information, or to apply: https://smpl.is/a61bj  hashtag#ITjobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#leadership hashtag#techjobs hashtag#opportunity

Why I Have Declined a Fully-Remote $7,150 Net/Month Offer.Recently, I was actively job hunting and got pretty far with a promising opportunity. I completed the technical task, passed the interviews, and received an offer from a well-known international company with a strong media presence and a quite ethical business model.The position was for a DevOps engineer. The terms were excellent: official B2B contract, fully remote work - I could work from anywhere, even a small village back home in Kazakhstan. They offered a three-week paid company bootcamp in Cyprus and a long-term collaboration. Some of their employees had been with the company for over 12 years - it sounded like a dream job.I had already arranged an early exit from my current work, started looking for tickets to Cyprus, and was mentally ready to sign the contract.But when the actual contract arrived, although it was generally fine, one detail immediately caught my attention: there was no liability limitation clause.For employees under standard labor law in almost any country, it is usually not an issue because labor laws protect employees against unlimited financial liability. But for B2B or contractor agreements, things are different - unless explicitly stated otherwise, the contractor can be held fully liable.As someone with significant DevOps experience, I know firsthand that mistakes can be costly. It might only take a few hours to accidentally cause damages worth several months of my salary. While Iâ€™ve never had a serious incident myself, I understand that no one is immune to risk - itâ€™s part of the job.So, I politely asked to add a simple clause: to cap the liability to a maximum of three months' salary.The HR representative immediately refused, saying, "This is our standard contract. Everyone signs it, and so should you." They told me theyâ€™ve never had any lawsuits and insisted there was no need to change anything. Moreover, I was repeatedly told that literally no one in the whole company, including legal, HR, and the hiring manager, understands my concern and I should just sign the contract as it is. The hiring manager allegedly is also under the same contract, has caused damages ranging into hundreds of thousands of USD before, and "everything was fine."I spent a lot of time carefully explaining my concern - that itâ€™s not about mistrust but about basic risk management - but they stuck to their position. Eventually, they gave me an ultimatum: sign it as-is, or walk away.I chose to walk away.I've been in this industry long enough to know: mistakes will happen eventually, and when they do, they can be very expensive. Signing a contract with unlimited personal liability would be like playing Russian roulette with my financial future. In my opinion it just wasn't worth it.

ğŸš§ How I Overcame a Major Project Failure ğŸ¤A few years ago, I was leading the deployment of a Node.js application to AWS Lightsail. Everything looked great on paper â€” the code was solid, the pipeline was configured, and the deadline was tight, but doable.Then came the failure.Right after deployment, the application didn't serve as expected. I could SSH into the server, the services were running, but users kept seeing a blank page. Logs showed no clear errors. We had to halt the rollout, and stakeholders were understandably frustrated.The problem? The app was starting from the wrong entry point â€” we had deployed index.ts, but our CI/CD pipeline defaulted to the wrong directory (/var/www/html). It was a classic case of â€œit worked on my machineâ€ â€” and it cost us valuable time.ğŸ’¡ What I Learned:Never assume environment consistency. Document and test deployment directories explicitly.Automate sanity checks post-deployment (even a simple curl to the home page couldâ€™ve flagged this earlier).Own the failure, but focus on the fix. I worked late into the night with my team, rewrote the pipeline, and redeployed from the correct entry point.Most importantly, I learned to communicate transparently with stakeholders during a crisis.Today, our deployments are smoother, and Iâ€™ve grown more confident handling surprises in production.ğŸ—£ï¸ Have you ever had a project crash and burn, only to bounce back stronger? Letâ€™s talk â€” your comeback story might inspire someone today.hashtag#TechLeadership hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CICD hashtag#FailureToSuccess hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#AWS hashtag#Lightsail hashtag#Nodejs hashtag#Reflection

Iâ€™m now firmly in my third month of un(der)employment. Itâ€™s been an interesting one.ğŸ‘¨ğŸ¼â€ğŸ’» Good News: I began working a FT job recently which is in a completely different world than where I came from, but in many ways not that different at all. Itâ€™s enough money to keep me off the stateâ€™s dime but just barely. Itâ€™s a shadow of my most recent salary and the first time Iâ€™ve had to actually punch a clock in (uuuugh) 30 years or more BUT itâ€™s a job and in lieu of a world that seems more likely to cut off its nose to spite its face than do anything that makes sense at all, Iâ€™ll take it. This is something I should have done the last time I was out of work. Idle hands, and all that.ğŸ‰ It shortens the resume gap, and if any of my potential future employers are reading this hopefully theyâ€™ll see that I am willing to do anything it takes to get the job done. Even if that job is just making the grocery budget manageable.â›”ï¸ DO NOT let your pride or ego get in your way. Take that random PT or FT gig while youâ€™re still seeking your next main gig. Get out of the house. Enjoy the process. You never know what might happen.â˜‘ï¸ Worst case - itâ€™s another hard reset and I make something cool out of this. Iâ€™ll add some new tools to my arsenal, meet some genuinely awesome people, and not be bored in the interim. IT/ Software Applications Manager Oceanside, CA (San Diego Metro) 135-160k+ DOE    About Us:   We are a growing leading manufacturer and supplier of premium consumer products for the automobile industry. We are seeking a dynamic IT Development Manager to lead our data, infrastructure, and software engineering team and drive the integration and optimization of our critical business systems.   Job Summary:   We are looking for an experienced IT Development Manager with exceptional communication and leadership skills to oversee the planning, execution, and success of our software development and integration projects. The ideal candidate will have a strong background in managing enterprise applications, particularly ERP, WMS, E-commerce, and EDI integrations. Why I Have Declined a Fully-Remote $7,150 Net/Month Offer.Recently, I was actively job hunting and got pretty far with a promising opportunity. I completed the technical task, passed the interviews, and received an offer from a well-known international company with a strong media presence and a quite ethical business model.The position was for a DevOps engineer. The terms were excellent: official B2B contract, fully remote work - I could work from anywhere, even a small village back home in Kazakhstan. They offered a three-week paid company bootcamp in Cyprus and a long-term collaboration. Some of their employees had been with the company for over 12 years - it sounded like a dream job.I had already arranged an early exit from my current work, started looking for tickets to Cyprus, and was mentally ready to sign the contract.But when the actual contract arrived, although it was generally fine, one detail immediately caught my attention: there was no liability limitation clause.For employees under standard labor law in almost any country, it is usually not an issue because labor laws protect employees against unlimited financial liability. But for B2B or contractor agreements, things are different - unless explicitly stated otherwise, the contractor can be held fully liable.As someone with significant DevOps experience, I know firsthand that mistakes can be costly. It might only take a few hours to accidentally cause damages worth several months of my salary. While Iâ€™ve never had a serious incident myself, I understand that no one is immune to risk - itâ€™s part of the job.So, I politely asked to add a simple clause: to cap the liability to a maximum of three months' salary.The HR representative immediately refused, saying, "This is our standard contract. Everyone signs it, and so should you." They told me theyâ€™ve never had any lawsuits and insisted there was no need to change anything. Moreover, I was repeatedly told that literally no one in the whole company, including legal, HR, and the hiring manager, understands my concern and I should just sign the contract as it is. The hiring manager allegedly is also under the same contract, has caused damages ranging into hundreds of thousands of USD before, and "everything was fine."I spent a lot of time carefully explaining my concern - that itâ€™s not about mistrust but about basic risk management - but they stuck to their position. Eventually, they gave me an ultimatum: sign it as-is, or walk away.I chose to walk away.I've been in this industry long enough to know: mistakes will happen eventually, and when they do, they can be very expensive. Signing a contract with unlimited personal liability would be like playing Russian roulette with my financial future. In my opinion it just wasn't worth it.

And when we apply for roles in your organization, weâ€™re not just looking for a jobâ€”weâ€™re offering *you* a chance to work *with us.*So, yesâ€”hire Indigenous professionals. ğŸš§ How I Overcame a Major Project Failure ğŸ¤A few years ago, I was leading the deployment of a Node.js application to AWS Lightsail. Everything looked great on paper â€” the code was solid, the pipeline was configured, and the deadline was tight, but doable.Then came the failure.Right after deployment, the application didn't serve as expected. I could SSH into the server, the services were running, but users kept seeing a blank page. Logs showed no clear errors. We had to halt the rollout, and stakeholders were understandably frustrated.The problem? The app was starting from the wrong entry point â€” we had deployed index.ts, but our CI/CD pipeline defaulted to the wrong directory (/var/www/html). It was a classic case of â€œit worked on my machineâ€ â€” and it cost us valuable time.ğŸ’¡ What I Learned:Never assume environment consistency. Document and test deployment directories explicitly.Automate sanity checks post-deployment (even a simple curl to the home page couldâ€™ve flagged this earlier).Own the failure, but focus on the fix. I worked late into the night with my team, rewrote the pipeline, and redeployed from the correct entry point.Most importantly, I learned to communicate transparently with stakeholders during a crisis.Today, our deployments are smoother, and Iâ€™ve grown more confident handling surprises in production.ğŸ—£ï¸ Have you ever had a project crash and burn, only to bounce back stronger? Letâ€™s talk â€” your comeback story might inspire someone today.hashtag#TechLeadership hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CICD hashtag#FailureToSuccess hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#AWS hashtag#Lightsail hashtag#Nodejs hashtag#Reflection

IT/ Software Applications Manager Oceanside, CA (San Diego Metro) 135-160k+ DOE    About Us:   We are a growing leading manufacturer and supplier of premium consumer products for the automobile industry. We are seeking a dynamic IT Development Manager to lead our data, infrastructure, and software engineering team and drive the integration and optimization of our critical business systems.   Job Summary:   We are looking for an experienced IT Development Manager with exceptional communication and leadership skills to oversee the planning, execution, and success of our software development and integration projects. The ideal candidate will have a strong background in managing enterprise applications, particularly ERP, WMS, E-commerce, and EDI integrations. This role requires a hands-on manager who can lead a team of software engineers, foster their growth, and ensure alignment with business objectives. This role involves approximately 40% hands-on work.   Responsibilities: â€¢	Lead and manage a team of software engineers, providing mentorship. â€¢	Plan and implement enterprise applications and related integrations (ERP, WMS, E-commerce, EDI). â€¢	Design, develop, and architect solutions that deliver value to the organization. â€¢	Manage the lifecycle of enterprise applications. â€¢	Collaborate with stakeholders to define project scope and objectives. â€¢	Automate release pipelines and testing. â€¢	Actively manage project timelines and resources.  Required Skills and Experience:  â€¢	Excellent communication skills. â€¢	Proven leadership and team management skills. â€¢	10+ years of experience in IT and software engineering roles. â€¢	5+ years of experience in a leadership role. â€¢	Experience implementing and maintaining enterprise applications (ERP, WMS). â€¢	Experience with ERP integrations (EDI, E-commerce). â€¢	Experience with .Net C# and other object-oriented programming languages. â€¢	Proficiency in DevOps management tools and code repositories. â€¢	Experience with SQL and SQL server. â€¢	Experience with cloud platforms (Azure and/or AWS). â€¢	Manufacturing experience is a plus.  What We Offer:  â€¢	Competitive Salary â€¢	Comprehensive Benefits Package â€¢	Growing department and team  More information, or to apply: https://smpl.is/a61bj  hashtag#ITjobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#leadership hashtag#techjobs hashtag#opportunity

Why I Have Declined a Fully-Remote $7,150 Net/Month Offer.Recently, I was actively job hunting and got pretty far with a promising opportunity. I completed the technical task, passed the interviews, and received an offer from a well-known international company with a strong media presence and a quite ethical business model.The position was for a DevOps engineer. The terms were excellent: official B2B contract, fully remote work - I could work from anywhere, even a small village back home in Kazakhstan. They offered a three-week paid company bootcamp in Cyprus and a long-term collaboration. Some of their employees had been with the company for over 12 years - it sounded like a dream job.I had already arranged an early exit from my current work, started looking for tickets to Cyprus, and was mentally ready to sign the contract.But when the actual contract arrived, although it was generally fine, one detail immediately caught my attention: there was no liability limitation clause.For employees under standard labor law in almost any country, it is usually not an issue because labor laws protect employees against unlimited financial liability. But for B2B or contractor agreements, things are different - unless explicitly stated otherwise, the contractor can be held fully liable.As someone with significant DevOps experience, I know firsthand that mistakes can be costly. It might only take a few hours to accidentally cause damages worth several months of my salary. While Iâ€™ve never had a serious incident myself, I understand that no one is immune to risk - itâ€™s part of the job.So, I politely asked to add a simple clause: to cap the liability to a maximum of three months' salary.The HR representative immediately refused, saying, "This is our standard contract. Everyone signs it, and so should you." They told me theyâ€™ve never had any lawsuits and insisted there was no need to change anything. Moreover, I was repeatedly told that literally no one in the whole company, including legal, HR, and the hiring manager, understands my concern and I should just sign the contract as it is. The hiring manager allegedly is also under the same contract, has caused damages ranging into hundreds of thousands of USD before, and "everything was fine."I spent a lot of time carefully explaining my concern - that itâ€™s not about mistrust but about basic risk management - but they stuck to their position. Eventually, they gave me an ultimatum: sign it as-is, or walk away.I chose to walk away.I've been in this industry long enough to know: mistakes will happen eventually, and when they do, they can be very expensive. Signing a contract with unlimited personal liability would be like playing Russian roulette with my financial future. In my opinion it just wasn't worth it.

ğŸš§ How I Overcame a Major Project Failure ğŸ¤A few years ago, I was leading the deployment of a Node.js application to AWS Lightsail. Everything looked great on paper â€” the code was solid, the pipeline was configured, and the deadline was tight, but doable.Then came the failure.Right after deployment, the application didn't serve as expected. I could SSH into the server, the services were running, but users kept seeing a blank page. Logs showed no clear errors. We had to halt the rollout, and stakeholders were understandably frustrated.The problem? The app was starting from the wrong entry point â€” we had deployed index.ts, but our CI/CD pipeline defaulted to the wrong directory (/var/www/html). It was a classic case of â€œit worked on my machineâ€ â€” and it cost us valuable time.ğŸ’¡ What I Learned:Never assume environment consistency. Document and test deployment directories explicitly.Automate sanity checks post-deployment (even a simple curl to the home page couldâ€™ve flagged this earlier).Own the failure, but focus on the fix. I worked late into the night with my team, rewrote the pipeline, and redeployed from the correct entry point.Most importantly, I learned to communicate transparently with stakeholders during a crisis.Today, our deployments are smoother, and Iâ€™ve grown more confident handling surprises in production.ğŸ—£ï¸ Have you ever had a project crash and burn, only to bounce back stronger? Letâ€™s talk â€” your comeback story might inspire someone today.hashtag#TechLeadership hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CICD hashtag#FailureToSuccess hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#AWS hashtag#Lightsail hashtag#Nodejs hashtag#Reflection

Iâ€™m now firmly in my third month of un(der)employment. Itâ€™s been an interesting one.ğŸ‘¨ğŸ¼â€ğŸ’» Good News: I began working a FT job recently which is in a completely different world than where I came from, but in many ways not that different at all. Itâ€™s enough money to keep me off the stateâ€™s dime but just barely. Itâ€™s a shadow of my most recent salary and the first time Iâ€™ve had to actually punch a clock in (uuuugh) 30 years or more BUT itâ€™s a job and in lieu of a world that seems more likely to cut off its nose to spite its face than do anything that makes sense at all, Iâ€™ll take it. This is something I should have done the last time I was out of work. Idle hands, and all that.ğŸ‰ It shortens the resume gap, and if any of my potential future employers are reading this hopefully theyâ€™ll see that I am willing to do anything it takes to get the job done. Even if that job is just making the grocery budget manageable.â›”ï¸ DO NOT let your pride or ego get in your way. Take that random PT or FT gig while youâ€™re still seeking your next main gig. Get out of the house. Enjoy the process. You never know what might happen.â˜‘ï¸ Worst case - itâ€™s another hard reset and I make something cool out of this. Iâ€™ll add some new tools to my arsenal, meet some genuinely awesome people, and not be bored in the interim. Wouldnâ€™t be the first timeâ€¦ğŸ™ğŸ» Thatâ€™s how I got into live events, after all.ğŸš¨ This job is also being super considerate about letting me take short-term event contracts as they come along, too. Itâ€™s a win-win, really.ğŸ¥º A lot of people I know continue to get laid off/made redundant/get Trumped. I hate it. Good people. Smart people. I am pulling for you all to land as close to what you want or need as you can. I am trying to share as many of your hashtag#OpenToWork posts as possible to help. Reach back if your new gig has a head count. ğŸ˜‰

IT/ Software Applications Manager Oceanside, CA (San Diego Metro) 135-160k+ DOE    About Us:   We are a growing leading manufacturer and supplier of premium consumer products for the automobile industry. We are seeking a dynamic IT Development Manager to lead our data, infrastructure, and software engineering team and drive the integration and optimization of our critical business systems.   Job Summary:   We are looking for an experienced IT Development Manager with exceptional communication and leadership skills to oversee the planning, execution, and success of our software development and integration projects. The ideal candidate will have a strong background in managing enterprise applications, particularly ERP, WMS, E-commerce, and EDI integrations. This role requires a hands-on manager who can lead a team of software engineers, foster their growth, and ensure alignment with business objectives. This role involves approximately 40% hands-on work.   Responsibilities: â€¢	Lead and manage a team of software engineers, providing mentorship. â€¢	Plan and implement enterprise applications and related integrations (ERP, WMS, E-commerce, EDI). â€¢	Design, develop, and architect solutions that deliver value to the organization. â€¢	Manage the lifecycle of enterprise applications. â€¢	Collaborate with stakeholders to define project scope and objectives. â€¢	Automate release pipelines and testing. â€¢	Actively manage project timelines and resources.  Required Skills and Experience:  â€¢	Excellent communication skills. â€¢	Proven leadership and team management skills. â€¢	10+ years of experience in IT and software engineering roles. â€¢	5+ years of experience in a leadership role. â€¢	Experience implementing and maintaining enterprise applications (ERP, WMS). â€¢	Experience with ERP integrations (EDI, E-commerce). â€¢	Experience with .Net C# and other object-oriented programming languages. â€¢	Proficiency in DevOps management tools and code repositories. â€¢	Experience with SQL and SQL server. â€¢	Experience with cloud platforms (Azure and/or AWS). â€¢	Manufacturing experience is a plus.  What We Offer:  â€¢	Competitive Salary â€¢	Comprehensive Benefits Package â€¢	Growing department and team  More information, or to apply: https://smpl.is/a61bj  hashtag#ITjobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#leadership hashtag#techjobs hashtag#opportunity

Why I Have Declined a Fully-Remote $7,150 Net/Month Offer.Recently, I was actively job hunting and got pretty far with a promising opportunity. I completed the technical task, passed the interviews, and received an offer from a well-known international company with a strong media presence and a quite ethical business model.The position was for a DevOps engineer. The terms were excellent: official B2B contract, fully remote work - I could work from anywhere, even a small village back home in Kazakhstan. They offered a three-week paid company bootcamp in Cyprus and a long-term collaboration. Some of their employees had been with the company for over 12 years - it sounded like a dream job.I had already arranged an early exit from my current work, started looking for tickets to Cyprus, and was mentally ready to sign the contract.But when the actual contract arrived, although it was generally fine, one detail immediately caught my attention: there was no liability limitation clause.For employees under standard labor law in almost any country, it is usually not an issue because labor laws protect employees against unlimited financial liability. But for B2B or contractor agreements, things are different - unless explicitly stated otherwise, the contractor can be held fully liable.As someone with significant DevOps experience, I know firsthand that mistakes can be costly. It might only take a few hours to accidentally cause damages worth several months of my salary. While Iâ€™ve never had a serious incident myself, I understand that no one is immune to risk - itâ€™s part of the job.So, I politely asked to add a simple clause: to cap the liability to a maximum of three months' salary.The HR representative immediately refused, saying, "This is our standard contract. Everyone signs it, and so should you." They told me theyâ€™ve never had any lawsuits and insisted there was no need to change anything. Moreover, I was repeatedly told that literally no one in the whole company, including legal, HR, and the hiring manager, understands my concern and I should just sign the contract as it is. The hiring manager allegedly is also under the same contract, has caused damages ranging into hundreds of thousands of USD before, and "everything was fine."I spent a lot of time carefully explaining my concern - that itâ€™s not about mistrust but about basic risk management - but they stuck to their position. Eventually, they gave me an ultimatum: sign it as-is, or walk away.I chose to walk away.I've been in this industry long enough to know: mistakes will happen eventually, and when they do, they can be very expensive. Signing a contract with unlimited personal liability would be like playing Russian roulette with my financial future. In my opinion it just wasn't worth it.

ğŸš§ How I Overcame a Major Project Failure ğŸ¤A few years ago, I was leading the deployment of a Node.js application to AWS Lightsail. Everything looked great on paper â€” the code was solid, the pipeline was configured, and the deadline was tight, but doable.Then came the failure.Right after deployment, the application didn't serve as expected. I could SSH into the server, the services were running, but users kept seeing a blank page. Logs showed no clear errors. We had to halt the rollout, and stakeholders were understandably frustrated.The problem? The app was starting from the wrong entry point â€” we had deployed index.ts, but our CI/CD pipeline defaulted to the wrong directory (/var/www/html). It was a classic case of â€œit worked on my machineâ€ â€” and it cost us valuable time.ğŸ’¡ What I Learned:Never assume environment consistency. Document and test deployment directories explicitly.Automate sanity checks post-deployment (even a simple curl to the home page couldâ€™ve flagged this earlier).Own the failure, but focus on the fix. I worked late into the night with my team, rewrote the pipeline, and redeployed from the correct entry point.Most importantly, I learned to communicate transparently with stakeholders during a crisis.Today, our deployments are smoother, and Iâ€™ve grown more confident handling surprises in production.ğŸ—£ï¸ Have you ever had a project crash and burn, only to bounce back stronger? Letâ€™s talk â€” your comeback story might inspire someone today.hashtag#TechLeadership hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CICD hashtag#FailureToSuccess hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#AWS hashtag#Lightsail hashtag#Nodejs hashtag#Reflection

Iâ€™m now firmly in my third month of un(der)employment. Itâ€™s been an interesting one.ğŸ‘¨ğŸ¼â€ğŸ’» Good News: I began working a FT job recently which is in a completely different world than where I came from, but in many ways not that different at all. Itâ€™s enough money to keep me off the stateâ€™s dime but just barely. Itâ€™s a shadow of my most recent salary and the first time Iâ€™ve had to actually punch a clock in (uuuugh) 30 years or more BUT itâ€™s a job and in lieu of a world that seems more likely to cut off its nose to spite its face than do anything that makes sense at all, Iâ€™ll take it. This is something I should have done the last time I was out of work. Idle hands, and all that.ğŸ‰ It shortens the resume gap, and if any of my potential future employers are reading this hopefully theyâ€™ll see that I am willing to do anything it takes to get the job done. Even if that job is just making the grocery budget manageable.â›”ï¸ DO NOT let your pride or ego get in your way. Take that random PT or FT gig while youâ€™re still seeking your next main gig. Get out of the house. Enjoy the process. You never know what might happen.â˜‘ï¸ Worst case - itâ€™s another hard reset and I make something cool out of this. Iâ€™ll add some new tools to my arsenal, meet some genuinely awesome people, and not be bored in the interim. Wouldnâ€™t be the first timeâ€¦ğŸ™ğŸ» Thatâ€™s how I got into live events, after all.ğŸš¨ This job is also being super considerate about letting me take short-term event contracts as they come along, too. Itâ€™s a win-win, really.ğŸ¥º A lot of people I know continue to get laid off/made redundant/get Trumped. I hate it. Good people. Smart people. I am pulling for you all to land as close to what you want or need as you can. I am trying to share as many of your hashtag#OpenToWork posts as possible to help. Reach back if your new gig has a head count. ğŸ˜‰

Why I Have Declined a Fully-Remote $7,150 Net/Month Offer.Recently, I was actively job hunting and got pretty far with a promising opportunity. I completed the technical task, passed the interviews, and received an offer from a well-known international company with a strong media presence and a quite ethical business model.The position was for a DevOps engineer. The terms were excellent: official B2B contract, fully remote work - I could work from anywhere, even a small village back home in Kazakhstan. They offered a three-week paid company bootcamp in Cyprus and a long-term collaboration. Some of their employees had been with the company for over 12 years - it sounded like a dream job.I had already arranged an early exit from my current work, started looking for tickets to Cyprus, and was mentally ready to sign the contract.But when the actual contract arrived, although it was generally fine, one detail immediately caught my attention: there was no liability limitation clause.For employees under standard labor law in almost any country, it is usually not an issue because labor laws protect employees against unlimited financial liability. But for B2B or contractor agreements, things are different - unless explicitly stated otherwise, the contractor can be held fully liable.As someone with significant DevOps experience, I know firsthand that mistakes can be costly. It might only take a few hours to accidentally cause damages worth several months of my salary. While Iâ€™ve never had a serious incident myself, I understand that no one is immune to risk - itâ€™s part of the job.So, I politely asked to add a simple clause: to cap the liability to a maximum of three months' salary.The HR representative immediately refused, saying, "This is our standard contract. Everyone signs it, and so should you." They told me theyâ€™ve never had any lawsuits and insisted there was no need to change anything. Moreover, I was repeatedly told that literally no one in the whole company, including legal, HR, and the hiring manager, understands my concern and I should just sign the contract as it is. The hiring manager allegedly is also under the same contract, has caused damages ranging into hundreds of thousands of USD before, and "everything was fine."I spent a lot of time carefully explaining my concern - that itâ€™s not about mistrust but about basic risk management - but they stuck to their position. Eventually, they gave me an ultimatum: sign it as-is, or walk away.I chose to walk away.I've been in this industry long enough to know: mistakes will happen eventually, and when they do, they can be very expensive. Signing a contract with unlimited personal liability would be like playing Russian roulette with my financial future. In my opinion it just wasn't worth it.

Think fast and get in touch, before *poof* itâ€™s gone! What are you waiting for? Opportunityâ€™s a fairy, flying fast - catch her! ğŸ«µğŸ¾

ğŸš§ How I Overcame a Major Project Failure ğŸ¤A few years ago, I was leading the deployment of a Node.js application to AWS Lightsail. Everything looked great on paper â€” the code was solid, the pipeline was configured, and the deadline was tight, but doable.Then came the failure.Right after deployment, the application didn't serve as expected. I could SSH into the server, the services were running, but users kept seeing a blank page. Logs showed no clear errors. We had to halt the rollout, and stakeholders were understandably frustrated.The problem? The app was starting from the wrong entry point â€” we had deployed index.ts, but our CI/CD pipeline defaulted to the wrong directory (/var/www/html). It was a classic case of â€œit worked on my machineâ€ â€” and it cost us valuable time.ğŸ’¡ What I Learned:Never assume environment consistency. Document and test deployment directories explicitly.Automate sanity checks post-deployment (even a simple curl to the home page couldâ€™ve flagged this earlier).Own the failure, but focus on the fix. I worked late into the night with my team, rewrote the pipeline, and redeployed from the correct entry point.Most importantly, I learned to communicate transparently with stakeholders during a crisis.Today, our deployments are smoother, and Iâ€™ve grown more confident handling surprises in production.ğŸ—£ï¸ Have you ever had a project crash and burn, only to bounce back stronger? Letâ€™s talk â€” your comeback story might inspire someone today.hashtag#TechLeadership hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CICD hashtag#FailureToSuccess hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#AWS hashtag#Lightsail hashtag#Nodejs hashtag#Reflection

Iâ€™m now firmly in my third month of un(der)employment. Itâ€™s been an interesting one.ğŸ‘¨ğŸ¼â€ğŸ’» Good News: I began working a FT job recently which is in a completely different world than where I came from, but in many ways not that different at all. Itâ€™s enough money to keep me off the stateâ€™s dime but just barely. Itâ€™s a shadow of my most recent salary and the first time Iâ€™ve had to actually punch a clock in (uuuugh) 30 years or more BUT itâ€™s a job and in lieu of a world that seems more likely to cut off its nose to spite its face than do anything that makes sense at all, Iâ€™ll take it. This is something I should have done the last time I was out of work. Idle hands, and all that.ğŸ‰ It shortens the resume gap, and if any of my potential future employers are reading this hopefully theyâ€™ll see that I am willing to do anything it takes to get the job done. Even if that job is just making the grocery budget manageable.â›”ï¸ DO NOT let your pride or ego get in your way. Take that random PT or FT gig while youâ€™re still seeking your next main gig. Get out of the house. Enjoy the process. You never know what might happen.â˜‘ï¸ Worst case - itâ€™s another hard reset and I make something cool out of this. Iâ€™ll add some new tools to my arsenal, meet some genuinely awesome people, and not be bored in the interim. Wouldnâ€™t be the first timeâ€¦ğŸ™ğŸ» Thatâ€™s how I got into live events, after all.ğŸš¨ This job is also being super considerate about letting me take short-term event contracts as they come along, too. Itâ€™s a win-win, really.ğŸ¥º A lot of people I know continue to get laid off/made redundant/get Trumped. I hate it. Good people. Smart people. I am pulling for you all to land as close to what you want or need as you can. I am trying to share as many of your hashtag#OpenToWork posts as possible to help. IT/ Software Applications Manager Oceanside, CA (San Diego Metro) 135-160k+ DOE    About Us:   We are a growing leading manufacturer and supplier of premium consumer products for the automobile industry. We are seeking a dynamic IT Development Manager to lead our data, infrastructure, and software engineering team and drive the integration and optimization of our critical business systems.   Job Summary:   We are looking for an experienced IT Development Manager with exceptional communication and leadership skills to oversee the planning, execution, and success of our software development and integration projects. The ideal candidate will have a strong background in managing enterprise applications, particularly ERP, WMS, E-commerce, and EDI integrations. This role requires a hands-on manager who can lead a team of software engineers, foster their growth, and ensure alignment with business objectives. This role involves approximately 40% hands-on work.   Responsibilities: â€¢	Lead and manage a team of software engineers, providing mentorship. â€¢	Plan and implement enterprise applications and related integrations (ERP, WMS, E-commerce, EDI). â€¢	Design, develop, and architect solutions that deliver value to the organization. â€¢	Manage the lifecycle of enterprise applications. â€¢	Collaborate with stakeholders to define project scope and objectives. â€¢	Automate release pipelines and testing. â€¢	Actively manage project timelines and resources.  Required Skills and Experience:  â€¢	Excellent communication skills. â€¢	Proven leadership and team management skills. â€¢	10+ years of experience in IT and software engineering roles. â€¢	5+ years of experience in a leadership role. â€¢	Experience implementing and maintaining enterprise applications (ERP, WMS). â€¢	Experience with ERP integrations (EDI, E-commerce). â€¢	Experience with .Net C# and other object-oriented programming languages. â€¢	Proficiency in DevOps management tools and code repositories. â€¢	Experience with SQL and SQL server. â€¢	Experience with cloud platforms (Azure and/or AWS). â€¢	Manufacturing experience is a plus.  What We Offer:  â€¢	Competitive Salary â€¢	Comprehensive Benefits Package â€¢	Growing department and team  More information, or to apply: https://smpl.is/a61bj  hashtag#ITjobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#leadership hashtag#techjobs hashtag#opportunity

Why I Have Declined a Fully-Remote $7,150 Net/Month Offer.Recently, I was actively job hunting and got pretty far with a promising opportunity. I completed the technical task, passed the interviews, and received an offer from a well-known international company with a strong media presence and a quite ethical business model.The position was for a DevOps engineer. The terms were excellent: official B2B contract, fully remote work - I could work from anywhere, even a small village back home in Kazakhstan. They offered a three-week paid company bootcamp in Cyprus and a long-term collaboration. Some of their employees had been with the company for over 12 years - it sounded like a dream job.I had already arranged an early exit from my current work, started looking for tickets to Cyprus, and was mentally ready to sign the contract.But when the actual contract arrived, although it was generally fine, one detail immediately caught my attention: there was no liability limitation clause.For employees under standard labor law in almost any country, it is usually not an issue because labor laws protect employees against unlimited financial liability. But for B2B or contractor agreements, things are different - unless explicitly stated otherwise, the contractor can be held fully liable.As someone with significant DevOps experience, I know firsthand that mistakes can be costly. It might only take a few hours to accidentally cause damages worth several months of my salary. While Iâ€™ve never had a serious incident myself, I understand that no one is immune to risk - itâ€™s part of the job.So, I politely asked to add a simple clause: to cap the liability to a maximum of three months' salary.The HR representative immediately refused, saying, "This is our standard contract. Everyone signs it, and so should you." They told me theyâ€™ve never had any lawsuits and insisted there was no need to change anything. Moreover, I was repeatedly told that literally no one in the whole company, including legal, HR, and the hiring manager, understands my concern and I should just sign the contract as it is. The hiring manager allegedly is also under the same contract, has caused damages ranging into hundreds of thousands of USD before, and "everything was fine."I spent a lot of time carefully explaining my concern - that itâ€™s not about mistrust but about basic risk management - but they stuck to their position. Eventually, they gave me an ultimatum: sign it as-is, or walk away.I chose to walk away.I've been in this industry long enough to know: mistakes will happen eventually, and when they do, they can be very expensive. Signing a contract with unlimited personal liability would be like playing Russian roulette with my financial future. In my opinion it just wasn't worth it.

ğŸš§ How I Overcame a Major Project Failure ğŸ¤A few years ago, I was leading the deployment of a Node.js application to AWS Lightsail. Everything looked great on paper â€” the code was solid, the pipeline was configured, and the deadline was tight, but doable.Then came the failure.Right after deployment, the application didn't serve as expected. I could SSH into the server, the services were running, but users kept seeing a blank page. Logs showed no clear errors. We had to halt the rollout, and stakeholders were understandably frustrated.The problem? The app was starting from the wrong entry point â€” we had deployed index.ts, but our CI/CD pipeline defaulted to the wrong directory (/var/www/html). It was a classic case of â€œit worked on my machineâ€ â€” and it cost us valuable time.ğŸ’¡ What I Learned:Never assume environment consistency. Document and test deployment directories explicitly.Automate sanity checks post-deployment (even a simple curl to the home page couldâ€™ve flagged this earlier).Own the failure, but focus on the fix. I worked late into the night with my team, rewrote the pipeline, and redeployed from the correct entry point.Most importantly, I learned to communicate transparently with stakeholders during a crisis.Today, our deployments are smoother, and Iâ€™ve grown more confident handling surprises in production.ğŸ—£ï¸ Have you ever had a project crash and burn, only to bounce back stronger? Letâ€™s talk â€” your comeback story might inspire someone today.hashtag#TechLeadership hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CICD hashtag#FailureToSuccess hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#AWS hashtag#Lightsail hashtag#Nodejs hashtag#Reflection

Iâ€™m now firmly in my third month of un(der)employment. Itâ€™s been an interesting one.ğŸ‘¨ğŸ¼â€ğŸ’» Good News: I began working a FT job recently which is in a completely different world than where I came from, but in many ways not that different at all. Itâ€™s enough money to keep me off the stateâ€™s dime but just barely. Itâ€™s a shadow of my most recent salary and the first time Iâ€™ve had to actually punch a clock in (uuuugh) 30 years or more BUT itâ€™s a job and in lieu of a world that seems more likely to cut off its nose to spite its face than do anything that makes sense at all, Iâ€™ll take it. This is something I should have done the last time I was out of work. Idle hands, and all that.ğŸ‰ It shortens the resume gap, and if any of my potential future employers are reading this hopefully theyâ€™ll see that I am willing to do anything it takes to get the job done. Even if that job is just making the grocery budget manageable.â›”ï¸ DO NOT let your pride or ego get in your way. Take that random PT or FT gig while youâ€™re still seeking your next main gig. Get out of the house. Enjoy the process. You never know what might happen.â˜‘ï¸ Worst case - itâ€™s another hard reset and I make something cool out of this. Iâ€™ll add some new tools to my arsenal, meet some genuinely awesome people, and not be bored in the interim. Wouldnâ€™t be the first timeâ€¦ğŸ™ğŸ» Thatâ€™s how I got into live events, after all.ğŸš¨ This job is also being super considerate about letting me take short-term event contracts as they come along, too. Itâ€™s a win-win, really.ğŸ¥º A lot of people I know continue to get laid off/made redundant/get Trumped. I hate it. Good people. Smart people. I am pulling for you all to land as close to what you want or need as you can. I am trying to share as many of your hashtag#OpenToWork posts as possible to help. Reach back if your new gig has a head count. ğŸ˜‰

IT/ Software Applications Manager Oceanside, CA (San Diego Metro) 135-160k+ DOE    About Us:   We are a growing leading manufacturer and supplier of premium consumer products for the automobile industry. We are seeking a dynamic IT Development Manager to lead our data, infrastructure, and software engineering team and drive the integration and optimization of our critical business systems.   Job Summary:   We are looking for an experienced IT Development Manager with exceptional communication and leadership skills to oversee the planning, execution, and success of our software development and integration projects. The ideal candidate will have a strong background in managing enterprise applications, particularly ERP, WMS, E-commerce, and EDI integrations. This role requires a hands-on manager who can lead a team of software engineers, foster their growth, and ensure alignment with business objectives. This role involves approximately 40% hands-on work.   Responsibilities: â€¢	Lead and manage a team of software engineers, providing mentorship. â€¢	Plan and implement enterprise applications and related integrations (ERP, WMS, E-commerce, EDI). â€¢	Design, develop, and architect solutions that deliver value to the organization. â€¢	Manage the lifecycle of enterprise applications. â€¢	Collaborate with stakeholders to define project scope and objectives. â€¢	Automate release pipelines and testing. â€¢	Actively manage project timelines and resources.  Required Skills and Experience:  â€¢	Excellent communication skills. â€¢	Proven leadership and team management skills. â€¢	10+ years of experience in IT and software engineering roles. â€¢	5+ years of experience in a leadership role. â€¢	Experience implementing and maintaining enterprise applications (ERP, WMS). â€¢	Experience with ERP integrations (EDI, E-commerce). â€¢	Experience with .Net C# and other object-oriented programming languages. â€¢	Proficiency in DevOps management tools and code repositories. â€¢	Experience with SQL and SQL server. â€¢	Experience with cloud platforms (Azure and/or AWS). â€¢	Manufacturing experience is a plus.  What We Offer:  â€¢	Competitive Salary â€¢	Comprehensive Benefits Package â€¢	Growing department and team  More information, or to apply: https://smpl.is/a61bj  hashtag#ITjobs hashtag#hiring hashtag#softwaredevelopment hashtag#leadership hashtag#techjobs hashtag#opportunity

Why I Have Declined a Fully-Remote $7,150 Net/Month Offer.Recently, I was actively job hunting and got pretty far with a promising opportunity. I completed the technical task, passed the interviews, and received an offer from a well-known international company with a strong media presence and a quite ethical business model.The position was for a DevOps engineer. The terms were excellent: official B2B contract, fully remote work - I could work from anywhere, even a small village back home in Kazakhstan. They offered a three-week paid company bootcamp in Cyprus and a long-term collaboration. Some of their employees had been with the company for over 12 years - it sounded like a dream job.I had already arranged an early exit from my current work, started looking for tickets to Cyprus, and was mentally ready to sign the contract.But when the actual contract arrived, although it was generally fine, one detail immediately caught my attention: there was no liability limitation clause.For employees under standard labor law in almost any country, it is usually not an issue because labor laws protect employees against unlimited financial liability. But for B2B or contractor agreements, things are different - unless explicitly stated otherwise, the contractor can be held fully liable.As someone with significant DevOps experience, I know firsthand that mistakes can be costly. It might only take a few hours to accidentally cause damages worth several months of my salary. While Iâ€™ve never had a serious incident myself, I understand that no one is immune to risk - itâ€™s part of the job.So, I politely asked to add a simple clause: to cap the liability to a maximum of three months' salary.The HR representative immediately refused, saying, "This is our standard contract. Everyone signs it, and so should you." They told me theyâ€™ve never had any lawsuits and insisted there was no need to change anything. Moreover, I was repeatedly told that literally no one in the whole company, including legal, HR, and the hiring manager, understands my concern and I should just sign the contract as it is. The hiring manager allegedly is also under the same contract, has caused damages ranging into hundreds of thousands of USD before, and "everything was fine."I spent a lot of time carefully explaining my concern - that itâ€™s not about mistrust but about basic risk management - but they stuck to their position. Eventually, they gave me an ultimatum: sign it as-is, or walk away.I chose to walk away.I've been in this industry long enough to know: mistakes will happen eventually, and when they do, they can be very expensive. Signing a contract with unlimited personal liability would be like playing Russian roulette with my financial future. In my opinion it just wasn't worth it.

ğŸš§ How I Overcame a Major Project Failure ğŸ¤A few years ago, I was leading the deployment of a Node.js application to AWS Lightsail. Everything looked great on paper â€” the code was solid, the pipeline was configured, and the deadline was tight, but doable.Then came the failure.Right after deployment, the application didn't serve as expected. I could SSH into the server, the services were running, but users kept seeing a blank page. Logs showed no clear errors. We had to halt the rollout, and stakeholders were understandably frustrated.The problem? The app was starting from the wrong entry point â€” we had deployed index.ts, but our CI/CD pipeline defaulted to the wrong directory (/var/www/html). It was a classic case of â€œit worked on my machineâ€ â€” and it cost us valuable time.ğŸ’¡ What I Learned:Never assume environment consistency. Document and test deployment directories explicitly.Automate sanity checks post-deployment (even a simple curl to the home page couldâ€™ve flagged this earlier).Own the failure, but focus on the fix. I worked late into the night with my team, rewrote the pipeline, and redeployed from the correct entry point.Most importantly, I learned to communicate transparently with stakeholders during a crisis.Today, our deployments are smoother, and Iâ€™ve grown more confident handling surprises in production.ğŸ—£ï¸ Have you ever had a project crash and burn, only to bounce back stronger? Letâ€™s talk â€” your comeback story might inspire someone today.hashtag#TechLeadership hashtag#DevOps hashtag#CICD hashtag#FailureToSuccess hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#AWS hashtag#Lightsail hashtag#Nodejs hashtag#Reflection
